title: The Odyssey
description: Odysseus's legendary 10-year journey home from the Trojan War, facing monsters, gods, and temptations along the way.

waypoints.name: Troy
waypoints.description: The legendary city where Odysseus fought for 10 years in the Trojan War. His cunning strategy of the Wooden Horse finally brought victory to the Greeks.

waypoints.name: Land of the Cicones
waypoints.description: First stop after leaving Troy. Odysseus and his men raided the city of Ismarus, but stayed too long celebrating their victory.

waypoints.name: Land of the Lotus Eaters
waypoints.description: A land where the inhabitants ate the lotus flower, which caused forgetfulness. Some of Odysseus's men ate the lotus and forgot their desire to return home.

waypoints.name: Island of the Cyclopes
waypoints.description: Home of Polyphemus, the one-eyed giant son of Poseidon. Odysseus blinded him to escape, earning Poseidon's eternal wrath.

waypoints.name: Aeolia (Island of Aeolus)
waypoints.description: The floating island of Aeolus, keeper of the winds. He gave Odysseus a bag containing all unfavorable winds, but curious crew members opened it near Ithaca.

waypoints.name: Land of the Laestrygonians
waypoints.description: Home of the giant cannibals who destroyed 11 of Odysseus's 12 ships by hurling boulders from the cliffs.

waypoints.name: Aeaea (Circe's Island)
waypoints.description: Island of the enchantress Circe, who turned Odysseus's men into pigs. With Hermes's help, Odysseus resisted her magic and became her lover for a year.

waypoints.name: The Underworld
waypoints.description: Following Circe's instructions, Odysseus sailed to the edge of the world to consult the prophet Tiresias in the realm of the dead.

waypoints.name: Island of the Sirens
waypoints.description: Home of the Sirens, whose enchanting song lured sailors to their deaths. Odysseus had his men plug their ears with wax while he listened tied to the mast.

waypoints.name: Strait of Scylla and Charybdis
waypoints.description: The narrow strait between the six-headed monster Scylla and the deadly whirlpool Charybdis. Odysseus chose to pass closer to Scylla, losing six men.

waypoints.name: Thrinacia (Island of the Sun)
waypoints.description: Sacred island where the cattle of the sun god Helios grazed. Despite warnings, the starving crew slaughtered the cattle, bringing divine punishment.
events: Trapped by storms for a month

waypoints.name: Ogygia (Calypso's Island)
waypoints.description: The remote island of the nymph Calypso, who kept Odysseus as her lover for seven years, offering him immortality if he would stay.

waypoints.name: Scheria (Land of the Phaeacians)
waypoints.description: Island of the seafaring Phaeacians, where Odysseus was washed ashore and found by Princess Nausicaa. King Alcinous heard his story and provided passage home.

waypoints.name: Ithaca
waypoints.description: Odysseus's homeland, where Penelope had waited faithfully for 20 years, fending off the suitors who sought her hand and Odysseus's throne.

title: Quest for the Golden Fleece
description: Jason and the Argonauts' epic voyage aboard the Argo to retrieve the Golden Fleece from Colchis, facing countless dangers and adventures.
source: Apollonius of Rhodes, Argonautica (3rd century BCE)

waypoints.name: Iolcos
waypoints.description: Starting point of the quest. King Pelias sent Jason to retrieve the Golden Fleece, believing it to be an impossible task that would kill his rival.

waypoints.name: Lemnos
waypoints.description: Island inhabited only by women who had killed their husbands. Queen Hypsipyle welcomed the Argonauts, and they stayed for some time.

waypoints.name: Cyzicus
waypoints.description: Island where King Cyzicus welcomed them, but after they departed, winds blew them back at night. In the darkness, they fought their hosts, killing the king.

waypoints.name: Mysia
waypoints.description: Where Heracles's companion Hylas was pulled into a spring by water nymphs. Heracles searched so long for him that the Argonauts left without him.

waypoints.name: Land of the Bebryces
waypoints.description: Kingdom of the brutal King Amycus, who challenged all visitors to a boxing match. Polydeuces (Pollux) defeated and killed him.

waypoints.name: Salmydessus
waypoints.description: Home of the blind prophet Phineus, tormented by Harpies who stole or fouled his food. The Boreads (sons of the North Wind) drove them away.
events: Receiving guidance for the Clashing Rocks

waypoints.name: Symplegades (Clashing Rocks)
waypoints.description: The Clashing Rocks at the entrance to the Black Sea that crushed ships between them. Following Phineus's advice, they released a dove first.

waypoints.name: Island of Ares
waypoints.description: Island sacred to Ares, inhabited by birds that shot their feathers like arrows. The Argonauts drove them off by clashing their shields.

waypoints.name: Colchis
waypoints.description: Kingdom of King Aeetes, where the Golden Fleece hung in a grove sacred to Ares, guarded by a sleepless dragon. Here Jason met Medea.
events: Medea falls in love with Jason

waypoints.name: Pursuit by Apsyrtus
waypoints.description: Medea's brother Apsyrtus pursued the Argonauts. In some versions, Medea killed and dismembered him to delay her father's pursuit.

waypoints.name: Aeaea (Circe's Island)
waypoints.description: The Argonauts sought purification from Circe, Medea's aunt, for the murder of Apsyrtus. She purified them but refused them hospitality.

waypoints.name: Island of the Sirens
waypoints.description: The Argonauts passed the Sirens safely because Orpheus played his lyre louder than their song, drowning out their deadly music.

waypoints.name: Strait of Scylla and Charybdis
waypoints.description: With the help of the sea goddess Thetis and the Nereids, the Argo was safely guided through the deadly strait.

waypoints.name: Crete
waypoints.description: The Argonauts encountered Talos, the bronze giant who guarded Crete. Medea used her magic to defeat him by removing the plug in his ankle.

waypoints.name: Iolcos (Return)
waypoints.description: Jason returned triumphant with the Golden Fleece and Medea as his bride, only to find that Pelias had killed his father. Medea tricked Pelias's daughters into killing him.

title: The Twelve Labors
description: Heracles's legendary twelve labors, assigned as penance for killing his family in a madness sent by Hera. These tasks took him across the known world and into the realm of the gods.

waypoints.name: Nemea
waypoints.description: Labor 1: The Nemean Lion. A monstrous lion with impenetrable golden fur terrorized the valley of Nemea. Heracles strangled it and wore its pelt as armor.
events: Skinning it with its own claws

waypoints.name: Lerna
waypoints.description: Labor 2: The Lernaean Hydra. A many-headed serpent that grew two heads for every one cut off. With his nephew Iolaus, Heracles burned each neck stump to prevent regrowth.

waypoints.name: Ceryneia
waypoints.description: Labor 3: The Ceryneian Hind. A sacred deer with golden antlers and bronze hooves, sacred to Artemis. Heracles chased it for a full year before capturing it alive.

waypoints.name: Mount Erymanthus
waypoints.description: Labor 4: The Erymanthian Boar. A giant boar that ravaged the countryside. Heracles drove it into deep snow and captured it alive in a net.
events: Capture of the boar in snow

waypoints.name: Elis (Augean Stables)
waypoints.description: Labor 5: The Augean Stables. King Augeas's stables held thousands of cattle and hadn't been cleaned in 30 years. Heracles diverted two rivers to wash them clean in a single day.
events: Diversion of the Alpheus and Peneus rivers

waypoints.name: Lake Stymphalus
waypoints.description: Labor 6: The Stymphalian Birds. Man-eating birds with bronze beaks and metallic feathers they could launch like arrows. Heracles used a rattle from Athena to flush them out.

waypoints.name: Crete
waypoints.description: Labor 7: The Cretan Bull. The bull that fathered the Minotaur. Heracles wrestled it into submission and brought it back to Eurystheus alive.
events: Release of the bull at Marathon

waypoints.name: Thrace
waypoints.description: Labor 8: The Mares of Diomedes. King Diomedes fed his horses human flesh. Heracles fed Diomedes to his own horses, which then became tame.
events: Founding of the city of Abdera

waypoints.name: Themiscyra
waypoints.description: Labor 9: The Belt of Hippolyta. Queen Hippolyta offered her belt willingly, but Hera spread rumors that caused the Amazons to attack.

waypoints.name: Erytheia
waypoints.description: Labor 10: The Cattle of Geryon. A three-bodied giant who lived on the island of Erytheia at the edge of the world. Heracles killed him and drove his cattle back to Greece.
events: Setting up the Pillars of Hercules
Borrowing the Cup of the Sun
Long journey home with the cattle

waypoints.name: Garden of the Hesperides
waypoints.description: Labor 11: The Apples of the Hesperides. Golden apples guarded by a dragon and the nymphs at the edge of the world. Heracles held up the sky while Atlas fetched them.
events: Holding up the sky for Atlas
Tricking Atlas into taking it back

waypoints.name: The Underworld
waypoints.description: Labor 12: Cerberus. The three-headed hound that guarded the gates of the Underworld. Heracles wrestled it with his bare hands and brought it to Eurystheus.
events: Freeing Theseus from the Chair of Forgetfulness
